name: Skullcap
summary: Skullcap (Scutellaria species) is a traditional herbal remedy used for its calming, anxiolytic, and sleep-promoting properties.
description: Skullcap refers to a group of herbs in the Scutellaria genus, most commonly American skullcap (Scutellaria lateriflora) and Chinese skullcap (Scutellaria baicalensis). American skullcap is traditionally used in Western herbalism as a nervine and mild anxiolytic, helping relieve nervous tension, insomnia, and restlessness. Chinese skullcap, in contrast, has been widely studied for its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and neuroprotective compounds such as baicalin and baicalein. While commonly used as a calming herb in integrative psychiatry, high-quality clinical evidence is limited. It is considered generally safe but must be distinguished from adulterated or mislabeled products, which have historically been linked to hepatotoxicity.

metadata.natural_source: Leaves and roots of Scutellaria species (lateriflora, baicalensis)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for therapeutic indications)

monitoring_required: Liver function if used long-term or with other hepatotoxic agents

items: Traditionally used as a calming nervine for anxiety and agitation
May promote relaxation and support sleep
Investigated for neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory effects

sections.text: American skullcap is thought to exert mild GABAergic effects, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and reducing excitability. Chinese skullcap contains flavonoids (baicalin, baicalein) with anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and neuroprotective properties, potentially modulating cytokine activity and protecting neurons.

adult.typical: 1–2 g of dried herb or equivalent extract up to 3 times daily
adult.note: Standardized extracts (e.g., 250–500 mg/day of baicalin) are sometimes used in clinical studies.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended outside supervised herbalist use.

sections.text: Calming effects may occur within hours; sleep benefits typically within days to weeks. Anti-inflammatory effects require longer-term use.

serious: Hepatotoxicity (rare, usually linked to adulterated products)

other: Avoid adulterated products; use only from trusted suppliers.
May enhance sedative effects of alcohol and CNS depressants.
Long-term high-dose use should be monitored for liver effects.

sections.geriatrics: Use cautiously due to sedation risk

sections.text: No tapering required; may discontinue without withdrawal effects.

items: American skullcap is primarily calming; Chinese skullcap has stronger anti-inflammatory effects.
Historical reports of liver toxicity were largely due to adulteration with germander (Teucrium).
Best used short-term for anxiety or sleep support, or adjunctively in integrative protocols.
